description: Borrowed from French sabre, from German Säbel, from Polish szabla, from Hungarian szablya. Cognate with Danish sabel, Russian са́бля (sáblja), Serbo-Croatian сабља, Sicilian sciàbbula.

entries.meaning: (UK, Canada) A light sword, sharp along the front edge, part of the back edge, and at the point.
(UK, Canada, fencing) A modern fencing sword modeled after the sabre.

verbs.description: sabre (third-person singular simple present sabres, present participle sabring, simple past and past participle sabred)

entries.meaning: (UK, Canada, transitive) To strike or kill with a sabre.
